children.subject:
Just my opinion: an insight like this would require the person to have taken all three classes, which is very unlikely.

Moreover, Math 170 doesn't seem to be offered in the near future.

For 127, you can search on this Piazza and you should get enough info.
Also note that there may be a bit of overlap between the LP in CS 170 and the simplex method stuff in Math 170, although 127 doesn't cover this material

At least for this semester, the overlap between the two courses is minuscule. They do duality of LPs in completely different ways (170 uses linear algebra tricks and farkas alternative, 127 uses lagrangian), and 127 doesn’t cover the simplex algorithm.

I'm in Math 170 and EECS 127 right now, so I can comment on my opinions of the two courses. But as the anon above said, it doesn't seem like Math 170 will be offered next semester anyways.

Overall, I have enjoyed 170 more than 127. At least to me, it feels like 127 doesn't mathematically prove much, and it seems to mostly be about shoving problems into a form such that we can plug it into a computer to solve. 127 is practical and is probably what you should take if you're looking to prepare for 189, but I've enjoyed the theory in 170 much more than 127. However, the first half of 170 is all about linear programs (LPs) and the simplex algorithm, which I didn't care for that much.

But take my opinions with a grain of salt. When I was deciding which courses to take for this semester, I saw a few people describing 170 as "outdated" and some people who found 127 more interesting.

history.content: I'm looking to take an optimization class next semester, and I was wondering what the difference was between the classes offered in the EECS, Math, and IEOR departments. Any insight would be appreciated!
history.subject: Math 170 vs EECS 127 vs IEOR optimization classes
